report.summary: Merge "New" and "Queue" tabs for easier use
report.label: feature request
report.description: As a user, I don't really think of "new" episodes as opposed to "queued" ones. I just want to know what new stuff there is to hear, and operate the app while giving it as little thought as possible. I would AntennaPod's interface to reflect this. I made a quick mockup that you can see here: As you see there's still a "Feeds" tab, but the "New" and "Queued" tabs are replaced by a single "Episodes" one. The episode being played is at the top of it, with some control buttons. Right below it are the episodes that have been downloaded and are ready to be listened. When the current episode ends, it goes to the History and is replaced by the first item in the list. Old, listened items are removed automatically and make room for new ones to be downloaded (also automatically) and added to the list. This way, supposing I have already subscribed to a selection of feeds that I like, I can keep listening to new episodes without ever worrying to check for new episodes, or having to download newer ones or reorder the list, or even ever leaving the "Episodes" screen. As a user, I would only have to press "Play" to start listening and "Pause" to stop, and no further action would ever be required from me.

report.label: feature request
report.description: Let me start off by saying thank you for producing high quality open source software and sharing it with everyone. I have been wanting to mess with android app development for a while, and I have started hacking at your code to understand how things work. Anyways, I've been playing around with the Google Reader API in the hopes of adding (some level of) google reader functionality to AntennaPod. At the very least it would be trivial to get an OAuth2 token from Android and then access the OMPL for a particular label directly from google reader as an import option (I've already gotten this level of functionality working in a dummy app). This would be way easier than the current OMPL import functionality and would only require one extra permission (USE_CREDENTIALS or something). Taking the idea further, one could imagine using google reader as a full on sync target for all feeds and read/unread statuses. This isn't so much a feature request as a request to gauge interest. If there is interest in such a feature (I know that Issue #21 is sort of a request in this direction) and no one is working on it, I'd like to contribute. If not, I can just try to develop the changes in a fork that I'll use myself and won't submit to Google Play.

report.label: feature request
report.description: This suggestion is included in a couple other issues (e.g. #125) but I think it's worth having its own issue. Now that episodes are added to the waiting list and the playing queue automatically, we need an easy way to dismiss the ones that don't interest us. Swiping away is the quickest and handiest way, and the one many Google apps (e.g. Gmail) are favouring: The user would just have to flick their finger to the left or right, and the episode is dismissed. Unlistened episodes (that is, those the user never even started listening) would be deleted and forgotten, and listened ones (even partially listened ones) would be skipped and go to the History. It could even be used at the top of the queue (that is, on the current episode) to skip the current episode and start listening to the next one, which would be an easy way to implement Skip without having to use extra buttons or UI elements.

report.summary: Auto-download and auto-enqueue should be separated
report.label: feature request
report.description: I love having the new auto-download feature, but I find that the auto-enqueuing of auto-downloaded podcasts is a bit too aggressive. I like being able to create a playlist from the available podcasts. While I might be interested in a podcast in general, certain episodes may not strike my fancy, and I like being able to leave them out of the playlist. But with the new auto-downloading, I don't seem to have that ability. I had only used AntennaPod for a few days before this update, but I remember there being a setting to enqueue podcasts when they were downloaded. This allowed me to see a list of available podcasts in the "Waiting List" section, and then add specific ones of them to the "Queue" section as they interested me. I like auto-downloading, though, so what seems ideal to me is for podcasts to be auto-downloaded into the "Waiting List," but allow for manual enqueuing -- possibly by returning the option to enable/disable enqueuing downloaded podcasts. I hope that makes sense. I really think AntennaPod is great! Thanks for all your hard work.

report.label: feature request
report.description: This issue is related to #135. A small reordering of the Network settings could make them clearer and avoid unwanted 3G usage. I think the Network settings should be as follows: AUTOMATIC UPDATE Both on WiFi and 3G. Only on WiFi. Never update automatically (selected by default). UPDATE INTERVAL (greyed out if automatic update is enabled) 1 hour / 2 hours / 4 hours / 8 hours / 12 hours / 24 hours. AUTOMATIC DOWNLOADING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES Both on WiFi and 3G. Only on WiFi (selected by default). Never download enqueued episodes automatically. AUTOMATIC STREAMING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES Checkbox: stream on 3G if it's their turn to play (unchecked by default). EPISODE CACHE 10 episodes / 20 episodes / 40 episodes / 60 episodes / 80 episodes / 100 episodes. WiFi FILTER Checkbox: treat unselected networks as if they were 3G. Checkboxes: list of known networks. There are several advantages to this: Data usage can be set more easily because you can set what the app can or cannot do while on 3G (and on WiFi) in a single field, without the need for an extra checkbox (as opposed to the "mobile updates" checkbox in the current version). All related options are together, and unrelated ones are separate: the automatic update setting is next to the update interval, but far from the WiFi filter (because the latter affects several other things). Last but not least, the "Automatic streaming of enqueued episodes" checkbox allows us to have a single action instead of the highly overlapping "Download" and "Enqueue", which is covered in #135.

report.label: feature request
report.description: Consider the following use case: User is subscribed to a number of podcasts User's queue is full with previously downloaded podcasts All the episodes in the queue are stale. The user doesn't want to listen to them (they already listened to them, they got behind, whatever). With the current model the user would have to manually remove all the episodes from the queue, one by one. That can be very time consuming and tedious with a long queue. If there were a 'empty queue' or 'clear queue' command the user could issue that command, all the episodes in the queue would be removed and then, when the system auto-updates, the queue would be filled with the latest episodes from their various subscriptions. Worthwhile?

report.description: Now that 1.2 is released it's time to start thinking about 1.3. There have been some suggestions for major UI improvements. Some visible, some under the covers. I think it would make sense to think through all the GUI related features and changes we want and try to make them all work well together. Some thoughts on improvements: Material design overhaul Use of RecyclerView in place of DSLV New subscription view (#848, #836) Better sharing of episodes (#861) Display of itunes 'explicit' tags (#724) Filtering by itunes 'explicit' tags (#725) Support for multiple queues I don't think this will happen in 1.3 Improve visibility of adding podcasts via iTunes - Done This is really the easiest way of adding podcasts Perhaps making it the first option users see and only labeling it 'search'? Download all episodes from a feed (#871, #520) Episode forward/back (#732) I bet there are some other good thoughts on what could be done. We should think hard about any changes to how we interact with the app, how these features would change them and how they could all work together.

report.label: feature request
report.description: Usually podcasts last way longer than songs, 60 and 90 minutes are quite common. And many of them have 'garbage' (ads, uncut overlapping times from other contiguous chapters or programs), that you would like to skip especially at the end of the episode, all while considering current episode as fully played. I guess that this is why a 'smart mark as played' optional time is offered; you can currently choose between No and 15/30/45/60 seconds. I would like to request to expand this to allow to select for several minutes. For example, my typical podcast has usually around 5 minutes of overlapping content at the end I have to skip to go to next episode. I would bet that 5 minutes for something 60/90/120 minutes long is way more frequent than 60 seconds, the longest I can choose. Adding 5 and 10 minutes to the current available options would more or less make it for many people with minimal developer effort. Alternatively, I would rather prefer to let me choose the amount in seconds I want, instead of being only offered a closed set of predefined values. This way developers would not need to guess which options to offer, simply let the user enter what they feel it fits him. That would be slightly more complicated to code, but not much; perhaps only some code to prevent absurdly high or negative values to be accepted would be in order for safety.

But it would be a great feature, if I could setup the maximum number of stored episodes for each subscription separately. I think this option could placed in the context menu of each subscription. And if the maximum is reached, the oldest, not played episode will be deleted. Episodes I've started, but not finished shouldn't count. Example for unplayed episodes: I will have 2 Episodes for Podcast X. I download Episode 001 and after a week 002. One week later Episode 003 is released. AntennaPod should remove Episode 001 and than download 003. Example for played episodes: I will have 2 Episodes for Podcast X. I download Episode 001 and after a week 002. I started (but not finished) Episode 001. One week later Episode 003 is released and should downloaded (becourse Episode 001 is not counting). An other week later Episode 004 is released and AntennaPod should delete Episode 002 and than download 004.
